['However, here are some common sources of radio interference:', 'Electromagnetic interference (EMI) - This can come from a variety of sources including electrical devices, power lines, and wireless devices.', 'Radio frequency interference (RFI) - This is similar to EMI but is specifically caused by radio waves.', 'Multipath interference - This occurs when a signal arrives at the receiver via multiple paths, causing interference.', 'Co-channel interference - This occurs when two or more devices are using the same frequency band, causing interference.', 'Adjacent channel interference - This occurs when a device is using a frequency band that is very close to the frequency band being used by another device, causing interference.', "Atmospheric interference - This can cause signal degradation due to the Earth's atmosphere.", 'Ionospheric interference - This can cause signal degradation due to the ionosphere.', 'Tropospheric interference - This can cause signal degradation due to the troposphere.', 'Auroral interference - This can cause signal degradation due to aurorae.', 'Satellite interference - This can occur when a satellite is in the line of sight of a radio transmitter or receiver, causing interference.', 'Space weather - This can cause signal degradation due to solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and other space weather phenomena.', 'Lightning - This can cause electromagnetic interference (EMI) that can affect radio signals.', 'Building structures - Buildings and other structures can cause multipath interference and block or attenuate radio signals.', 'Terrain - Hills, mountains, and other terrain features can cause signal degradation or blocking.', 'Weather - Weather conditions such as rain, fog, and snow can affect radio signals and cause interference.', 'Additionally, the specific sources of interference will depend on the frequency band and location of the radio system.']

['Arena - A large, circular or oval-shaped space, often used for outdoor performances like opera.', 'Aria - A self-contained portion of an opera, typically featuring a solo vocalist and accompaniment.', 'Chorus - A group of singers who perform together in an opera, often providing background harmony or commentary.', 'Diva - A highly skilled female singer, particularly in the world of opera.', 'Duet - A musical piece performed by two soloists, often in an opera.', 'Ensemble - A group of singers or actors who perform together in an opera or other theatrical work.', 'Fugue - A complex and intricate musical composition, often used in baroque opera.', 'Leitmotif - A recurring musical theme associated with a particular character or idea in an opera.', 'Libretto - The text of an opera, including the lyrics and dialogue.', 'Maestro - A conductor or director of an opera company.', 'Mezzo-soprano - A type of female singing voice that is lower than a soprano but higher than an alto.', 'Opera buffa - A comic opera, often featuring satire and farce.', 'Opera seria - A serious opera, often with complex plots and high-brow themes.', 'Overture - The introductory music to an opera or other theatrical work.', "Piano - A musical instrument used in many operas, particularly in the more intimate moments of a character's emotional journey.", 'Recitative - A style of singing in which the words are spoken rather than sung, often used in opera to advance the plot or provide exposition.', 'Scene - A section of an opera that takes place in a specific location or setting.', 'Soprano - A type of female singing voice that is higher than an alto but lower than a mezzo-soprano.', 'Tenor - A type of male singing voice that is higher than a baritone but lower than a countertenor.', 'Trio - A musical composition for three voices or instruments, often used in opera to add variety and interest to the score.']
